close_symbols: struct MHD_Daemon (definition, in particular: options, tid, epoll_fd, thread_stack_size, pool_size, connections, connection_limit, notify_connection)
struct MHD_Connection (definition, in particular: pool, tid, socket_fd, epoll_state, socket_context, addr, addr_len, tls_session)
explanation:
To decide whether any controlling expressions in new_connection_process_ are compile-time or otherwise invariant (and thus violate MISRA C “Controlling expressions shall not be invariant”), the analyzer must know which expressions are fixed at compile time vs dependent on runtime state. The listed symbols are the only items in or around the function that can make a controlling expression invariant or introduce compile-time-only control flow: 

- MHD_USE_THREADS (preprocessor macro): The presence/absence of this macro changes the compiled code. In the !MHD_USE_THREADS branch the source contains the literal if (1) — an obviously invariant controlling expression — so the analyzer must know whether MHD_USE_THREADS is defined for the build being analyzed. 

- EPOLL_SUPPORT (preprocessor macro): Inclusion of the epoll-related block (which contains further conditionals) depends on this macro. Whether those conditionals exist at all depends on EPOLL_SUPPORT, so the macro is needed to determine which control expressions are present.

- MHD_USE_TURBO (macro / bitmask): Used in the test (daemon->options & MHD_USE_TURBO). If MHD_USE_TURBO were defined as zero (or otherwise affect compile-time behavior), that could make the controlling expression invariant; the analyzer must know its definition/value.

- struct MHD_Daemon (definition): Many controlling expressions read daemon fields (e.g. daemon->options, daemon->tid, daemon->epoll_fd, daemon->connections, daemon->connection_limit, daemon->notify_connection). The analyzer must know the types and qualifiers (e.g. whether any of these fields are const or compile-time fixed) to determine if those tests can be invariant.

- struct MHD_Connection (definition): Several conditionals test connection fields (e.g. connection->pool, connection->tid, connection->socket_fd, connection->epoll_state, connection->addr, connection->tls_session). The analyzer needs the structure layout and any qualifiers to judge whether those expressions could be invariant.

- MHD_D_IS_USING_THREAD_PER_CONN_(daemon) (macro/function): Appears in multiple if tests (both positive and negated). If this macro expands to a literal constant (or is an inline that returns a compile-time constant), the tests would be invariant. The analyzer must inspect its definition/implementation to decide.

- MHD_D_IS_USING_EPOLL_(daemon) (macro/function): Used as a controlling expression for an important branch. The analyzer must know whether it is purely a runtime predicate or can be resolved at compile time.

- MHD_create_named_thread_ (function): The controlling expression if (! MHD_create_named_thread_(...)) depends on this function’s return behaviour. To rule out invariance (e.g. if it were implemented as a macro returning a constant in some builds), the analyzer must inspect its implementation or macro definition.

- epoll_ctl (syscall/wrapper): The code branches on the runtime result of epoll_ctl. If epoll_ctl were stubbed out or defined as a constant-returning wrapper in the build, the controlling expression could be invariant; the analyzer must know the actual epoll_ctl used in the build.

(Other symbols in the function, e.g. MHD_pool_create, MHD_pool_destroy, MHD_DLOG, the enum values MHD_YES/MHD_NO, or the notify_connection function pointer, are not required to determine whether the controlling expressions themselves are compile-time invariant — they affect runtime behavior but do not make the controlling expressions syntactically constant across builds. The above list focuses only on symbols that can make the controlling expressions invariant or remove/introduce those expressions at compile time.)
